title: After loss to Warren, Republican John Deaton announces another run for Senate
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: John Deaton, a Marine veteran and lawyer, announces his candidacy for Sen. Ed Markey's seat in the 2026 election.
Deaton criticized Markey's long tenure and highlighted his own military background and personal experiences in his campaign.
Markey, 80, faces a primary challenge from Rep. Seth Moulton, as well as potential Democratic contender Rep. Ayanna Pressley.

title: What will the Red Sox target this offseason? Craig Breslow maps out Boston’s priorities.
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: The Red Sox are seeking a top pitcher to pair with Garrett Crochet for the 2026 rotation.
Boston is exploring trades and free agency to bolster their lineup with power hitters like Kyle Schwarber.
Craig Breslow emphasizes maintaining future competitiveness while addressing current roster needs.

title: Zdeno Chara’s 10 most memorable moments with the Bruins
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Zdeno Chara inducted into the Hockey Hall of Fame, recognizing his impactful 14-year tenure as Bruins captain.
Chara's signing in 2006 sparked Boston's resurgence, leading to multiple Stanley Cup Final appearances.
Chara set the record for hardest shot in NHL history at 108.8 mph during the 2012 All-Star Game.

title: Bill Belichick reflects on ‘learning curve’ during first season coaching college football
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Bill Belichick reflects on North Carolina's first season struggles, highlighting the learning curve from NFL to college coaching.
The Tar Heels are tenth in ACC standings with a 4-5 record, needing two wins to match last year's total.
UNC improved after a four-game losing streak, with recent victories over Syracuse and Stanford boosting their performance.

title: Patriots have 15 players land on injury report, but get some good news
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Patriots prepare for Thursday's game against the Jets with 15 players on the injury report.
Kayshon Boutte and Rhamondre Stevenson are limited participants after missing Sunday's game.
Austin Hooper misses practice due to a concussion, while others like Marcus Jones have limited participation.

title: Georgia man allegedly stole millions in unclaimed Mass. property
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Shaka Stayman, 44, from Georgia, is accused of stealing over $1.1 million from unclaimed Massachusetts property funds.
Stayman faces 25 charges including larceny, money laundering, and use of false documents, per the Massachusetts Attorney General.
Stayman allegedly targeted deceased Massachusetts residents, using false identities to claim unclaimed property and rerouting funds.

title: TreVeyon Henderson explained why he looked at the sideline during key TD run
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: TreVeyon Henderson looked to the sideline for guidance during a key touchdown run against the Buccaneers.
The Patriots won despite Tampa Bay scoring late, as Stefon Diggs secured an onside kick recovery.
Henderson had his first 100-yard game and more than one touchdown, stepping up in Rhamondre Stevenson's absence.

title: Mason Lohrei is latest Bruins player to respond from a Marco Sturm benching
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Mason Lohrei returned to the Bruins lineup with two assists in a 5-3 win over the Maple Leafs.
Lohrei had been benched for five games due to defensive struggles under coach Marco Sturm's system.
The Bruins have seen positive responses from players, like Lohrei, following lineup changes and benchings.

title: Petitioners gathering signatures to repeal legal marijuana accused of misleading voters
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Petitioners gathering signatures to repeal legal marijuana in Massachusetts face accusations of misleading voters about the petition's content.
The Attorney General’s Office has received complaints but cannot confirm investigations into claims of signature collectors providing false information.
The Coalition for a Healthy Massachusetts denies encouraging misinformation, attributing accusations to confusion or deliberate opposition tactics.

title: Massachusetts state payroll hits $9B in 2025 — UMass system dominates
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: Massachusetts state payroll reached $9.19 billion in 2025, a decrease from last year's $10.26 billion.
UMass system employed all of the top 15 highest-paid state employees, totaling $1.55 billion in payroll expenditures.
UMass Men's Basketball Coach Frank Martin was the highest-paid state employee with a salary of $1,955,216.
